name: Winchester Country Club
description: One of only seven courses ever co-designed by Robert Trent Jones Sr. and Jr., Winchester Country Club unfolds across 223 forested acres in the Sierra Nevada foothills above Sacramento. Perched at 1,800 feet — below the snow and above the fog — this private club offers panoramic views of both the Sierra peaks and the Sacramento Valley. Massive granite outcroppings border the fairways, streams wind through the layout, and towering pines frame every shot. Ranked among California's top 25 courses by Golf Digest and winner of Golf Inc.'s Clubhouse of the Year.
designer: Robert Trent Jones Sr. & Robert Trent Jones Jr.

faqs.question: Can groups play Winchester on a Reno/Tahoe golf trip?
faqs.answer: Yes — Winchester is the ideal first or last stop for groups traveling I-80 between Sacramento and Reno-Tahoe. We coordinate tee times, logistics, and pairing with your full trip itinerary. Contact us for private club access and group rates.

faqs.question: What makes Winchester different from the Reno-Tahoe courses?
faqs.answer: Winchester sits in the Sierra foothills at 1,800 feet — warmer and drier than the Tahoe courses, with longer playing seasons. The RTJ Sr. & Jr. co-design is one of only seven such collaborations ever, and the 35,000 sq ft European hunting lodge-style clubhouse won Golf Inc.'s Clubhouse of the Year.

faqs.question: Is Winchester a private club? How do groups get access?
faqs.answer: Winchester is a private club, but Golf the High Sierra can arrange group access for visiting golf groups as part of a multi-course trip package. Call us at 888-584-8232 for availability and private club booking.

meta.title: Winchester Country Club | RTJ Sr. & Jr. Golf on I-80 Corridor
meta.description: Play Winchester Country Club in Meadow Vista — a rare Robert Trent Jones Sr. & Jr. co-design in the Sierra foothills. The perfect first or last stop on your Reno-Tahoe golf trip.

bodyText: Play Winchester Country Club in Meadow Vista — a rare Robert Trent Jones Sr. & Jr. co-design in the Sierra foothills. The perfect first or last stop on your Reno-Tahoe golf trip.

Perched at 1,800 feet in the Sierra Nevada foothills just off Interstate 80 past Auburn, Winchester Country Club is the course your group should experience on the way into or out of Reno-Tahoe. This is one of only seven courses in the world co-designed by the legendary father-son team of Robert Trent Jones Sr. and Robert Trent Jones Jr., and it plays through three distinct landscapes: steep woodlands, rolling prairies, and dramatic granite outcroppings.

The course encompasses 223 forested acres with streams, lakes, and natural rock formations woven into every hole. Five sets of tees ranging from 5,144 to 7,108 yards make the layout playable for groups of all skill levels, while three par threes stretching over 200 yards demand bold shot-making from the back tees. The 35,000-square-foot clubhouse, built in the style of a European hunting lodge, won Golf Inc.'s Clubhouse of the Year and houses fine dining, a pub, and the Jones Library — ideal for post-round gatherings.

tips.title: The I-80 Corridor Play
tips.content: Winchester sits just 15 minutes off I-80 past Auburn. For groups flying into Sacramento, it's the ideal warm-up round before continuing to Reno or Tahoe. On the return trip, it's a spectacular final round before heading home. The elevation at 1,800 feet means warmer temperatures and a longer season than the mountain courses.

tips.title: Golf The High Sierra
tips.content: Book your next group golf trip with us!

pointOfView: Winchester is the hidden weapon in any Reno-Tahoe golf trip itinerary. Nestled in the Sierra foothills right off I-80, it's the perfect course to bookend your journey — a warm-up round on arrival or a grand finale before heading home. The RTJ Sr. & Jr. pedigree is unmistakable: dramatic elevation changes, granite boulders framing fairways, and greens that reward precision over power. The course plays through three completely different landscapes in 18 holes, keeping every member of your group engaged from the first tee to the lodge-style clubhouse. At 1,800 feet, you're below the Tahoe snow and above the Sacramento fog — the sweet spot for year-round golf conditions. The clubhouse alone is worth the trip: fine dining with views over the course, a cozy pub, and the Jones Library for private group dinners. Winchester turns a drive-through into a destination.
contentParagraphs: Play Winchester Country Club in Meadow Vista — a rare Robert Trent Jones Sr. & Jr. co-design in the Sierra foothills. The perfect first or last stop on your Reno-Tahoe golf trip.

Perched at 1,800 feet in the Sierra Nevada foothills just off Interstate 80 past Auburn, Winchester Country Club is the course your group should experience on the way into or out of Reno-Tahoe. This is one of only seven courses in the world co-designed by the legendary father-son team of Robert Trent Jones Sr. and Robert Trent Jones Jr., and it plays through three distinct landscapes: steep woodlands, rolling prairies, and dramatic granite outcroppings.

The course encompasses 223 forested acres with streams, lakes, and natural rock formations woven into every hole. Five sets of tees ranging from 5,144 to 7,108 yards make the layout playable for groups of all skill levels, while three par threes stretching over 200 yards demand bold shot-making from the back tees.

The 35,000-square-foot clubhouse, built in the style of a European hunting lodge, won Golf Inc.'s Clubhouse of the Year and houses fine dining, a pub, and the Jones Library — ideal for post-round group gatherings and corporate events.

Golf Digest has ranked Winchester among California's top 25 courses and #1 in the Sacramento Valley. The course sits at a unique elevation sweet spot — below the Tahoe snow, above the valley fog — offering a longer playing season than the mountain courses on your itinerary.

featuredHole.title: Hole #18 — Par 4
featuredHole.description: Winchester's dramatic finishing hole sweeps uphill toward the grand European-style clubhouse. Massive granite boulders frame the fairway, demanding a precise drive between the rocks and a bold approach shot. The green sits below the clubhouse terrace, where your group can watch the final putts drop — a signature closer that Golf Digest panelists have called 'a stunner with great land movement.'

teeTimeInfo: Private club — group access arranged through Golf the High Sierra. Call 888-584-8232.
